title-group.article-title: Eco-friendly approach in supercapacitor application: CuZnCdO nanosphere decorated in reduced graphene oxide nanosheets

institution-wrap.institution: St. Joseph’s College (Autonomous) (Affiliated to Bharathidasan University)

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: The novel material CuZnCdO metal nanoparticles have been synthesized with different concentrations through green synthesis using fresh A. heterophyllus leaf extract as a reducing agent and graphene oxide derived from A. heterophyllus dead leaves. XRD, FESEM, EDAX, FTIR and FT-RAMAN analysis confirms the structural properties of rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles. BET has been used to investigate the surface area of the nanoparticles. It is a very challenging material that shows the highest specific capacitance of 882.5 F/g with non-hazardous and eco-friendly. Without any decay, the charge carrier concentration has performed up to 5000 cycles which indicates the material has good stability. The energy density and power density has been calculated by Ragone plot. This illustrates that the material has high capacitive behavior.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In decades, Graphene has a large scale of tremendous applications which is used in our day to day life like optical communications, satellite communications, optoelectronic devices, non-linear applications, terra hertz generations, bio-sensors, biomedical applications, lasers, photocatalysts, OLEDs, solar cells and supercapacitor applications [1, 2]. In recent days Graphene-based metallic oxide materials have more attention for using energy storage and conversion device, especially reproducing the biowaste into energy conversion via the chemical and physical method, and also many of them have attempted the green methodology for large scale productions [3–5].

Summarily, there is a great interest in producing a high power density energy storage system with a rapid demanding in the electric vehicles and portable electronic devices for a conservative process [6, 7]. Electrochemical capacitors are having high power density, fast charging and discharging process, long cycle period, high specific capacitance, ion diffusion, fast electron transfer, cyclic stability, equivalent series resistance, and charge transfer resistance [8, 9]. The electrode material is the most important key component which determines the electrochemical behavior of the supercapacitors [10]. Mainly conducting polymers [11], polyaniline, polypyrrole [12], transition metal oxides or hydroxide materials like nickel oxide [13, 14], cobalt oxide [15], magnesium oxide, calcium oxide, ruthenium oxide [16], manganese oxide, activated carbon, carbon nanotubes [17], fullerenes, graphene [18, 19], and mixed oxide compounds [20, 21] have been used as electrode materials.

Mainly, nowadays the researchers are having a great interest in green approach especially using the biowaste to prepare graphene or graphene composites to bulk production for energy storage devices or electrochemical applications. In recent literatures different type of hybrid material as an electrode for supercapacitors has been reported such as, porous carbon nanoparticles from bio-waste materials [22], Chemical Properties of Green Synthesized Porous Carbon Nanoparticles [23], Highly ordered mesoporous carbons materials [24], Emerging CoMn-LDH @ MnO2 electrode materials [25], MCo2O4@MCo2S4@PPy (M = Ni, Zn) sandwich structure for energy storage materials [26], CoMoO4@MoZn22 core–shell structures [27], polypyrrole (PPy) modified MoS2/Ni3S2 (MNS@PPy) as a promising electrode material for supercapacitor applications [28].

Copper oxide is a transparent metal oxide which is a great promising material for energy conversion and storage devices. As a basic p-type metal oxide with a precise band gab (Eg¼ 1.2 eV), CuO has been used as a part of dynamic anode materials, superconductors, sensors, and heterogeneous catalyst. It is used for manufacturing sunlight based cells, as a result of its photoconductive and photochemical properties. In particular, CuO has been explored as an anode material for high-control electrochemical pseudocapacitors due to its unlimited resources, ecological similarity, cost ampleness and perfect pseudocapacitive qualities [4].

In order to compare with the other metal oxides for Electric Double Layer Capacitors and Ultracapacitors, the Copper oxide is an eminent material which is attributed to the wide bandgap, the electrical property with high stability, and cost-effective. It vows a good conductivity and electron transfer capability, surface area and high charge carrier concentration which is an adequate electrode material for supercapacitor applications [29–31]. Many of the researchers are adding the various dopants into CuO metal oxides for improving the performance and efficiency of supercapacitors [32, 33]. Mainly they are focusing on the combination of Graphene, Polymers, and CNT in metal compounds for the improvement of electrical conductivity and thermal stability of the devices [34, 35]. Graphene is an arrangement of single layer and bilayer carbon atoms with a honeycomb or benzene like structure that holds the great ability for energy applications owing to its high conductivity and high specific surface area. The restacking and exfoliation process of bilayer and multilayered graphene might suppress the efficiency and conductivity of electrochemical performance [36–38].

Like other metal oxides, CuO based Graphene oxide pseudocapacitors must achieve high particular surface territory, high electrical conductivity, and a quick cation dispersion procedure to accomplish high power densities and vitality densities [39, 40]. Especially it has large carrier concentration and high electrical conductivity which is an advisable material for the future generation. As reported in the article [41] that CuO is an emanating material for energy storage devices. Moreover, we made a challenging attempt to synthesize the reduced graphene oxide from biowaste and CuZnCdO metal oxide with different concentrations of dopants via green route is eco-friendly which may deteriorate the toxicity of the material.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Copper Chloride (CuCl2), Zinc Chloride (ZnCl2), and Cadmium chloride (CdCl2) from Sigma Aldrich with AR grade were used as a precursor for the synthesis of CuZnCdO nanoparticles. A. heterophyllus leaves were collected from home premises.

sec.title: Synthesis of reduced graphene oxide
sec.p: The reduced Graphene oxide has been synthesized by a one-step pyrolysis method. A. heterophyllus dead leaves were crushed in mortar and washed several times with deionized water, then washed with methanol and Hcl to remove the impurities and the final substance was calcined at 1200 °C for 1 h then slowly reduced to room temperature, after this heating process the blackish powder was obtained, and then it was sonicated for 1 h, washed and centrifuged with methanol and deionized water, finally black graphene precipitate was obtained, then it was kept in the darkroom for 3 days and the aging process has been taken place. The graphene precipitate was dissipated in a water or methanol mixture and centrifuged for 2 h to obtain Graphene oxide sheets. The thermal reduction has undertaken to produce reduced graphene oxide, so the final substance has been calcined at 500 °C for 3 h.

sec.title: Preparation of plant extract
sec.p: The collected fresh leaves of A. heterophyllus have been washed thoroughly with the tap water to amputate the epiphytes and the necrotic, then using deionized water to remove the detritus presented in the plants, and then it was shadow dried for 2 days in a dark room and then crushed using agate mortar. For the plant extract preparation, 10 g of the dried powder is mixed with 100 ml of deionized water and boiled at 100 °C for 30 min. The subsequent solution is filtered until no impenetrable material appeared in the extract solution.

sec.title: Synthesis of rGO/CuZnCdO
sec.p:
The green approach was used for synthesizing the Cu1−2XZnXCdOX metal oxide nanoparticles with different concentrations X = 0.1 (S1), 0.15 (S2), 0.2 (S3) respectively. The experimental method has been shown in Fig. 1. Gradually Copper Chloride (CuCl2), Zinc Chloride (ZnCl2), and Cadmium chloride (CdCl2) were dissolved in 100 ml of deionized water one by one and stirred vigorously for 2 h, after this adding the prepared plant extract of A. heterophyllus fresh leaves in drop wise as a reducing agent until pH of the solution was adjusted till 8. Then 0.5 gm of rGO is dispersed in 10 ml of methanol kept under the sonicator for 1 h and added to the above solution. After the continuous stirring for 2 h, the precipitate was centrifuged and washed with HCl for removing the impurities, and then it was kept under the darkroom for 24 h and dried at 300 °C. Similarly, it was reciprocated for all the other concentrations.Fig. 1
Experimental method for rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles

sec.title: Characterization techniques
sec.p: X-ray diffraction pattern (PANalytical, X’Pert-PRO MPD) was investigated utilizing Cu Ka radiation for structural analysis. The specific surface area, pore-volume, and pore size have been measured by utilizing the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) has revealed the surface morphology of the synthesized material utilizing a Jeol JSM-6390 LV microscope at an accelerating voltage of 4.9 kV. The atomic composition of each material was characterized by Energy-Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS). Jasco V530 UV–visible spectrophotometer was investigated to study the absorption and bandgap of the material. The Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectra were attained by a Vertex 70v FTIR spectrophotometer (BRUKER USA) to confirm the presence of functional groups. Raman spectrum was recorded using the LabRAM HR (UV) system with an excitation of 532 nm near IR laser light which affirms the presents of Graphene. Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) was performed in the electrochemical workstation (CHI 660, China) with a three-electrode system. A platinum plate and a saturated Ag/AgCl were utilized as the counter electrode and reference electrode, and rGO/CdCuZnO as a modified working electrode.

sec.title: X-ray diffraction analysis
sec.p:
The X-ray Diffraction Pattern of rGO/CuZnCdO shown in Fig. 2. The peaks were found at 16° and 28° corresponding to (101) and (112) plane which consists of Cu4O3 tetragonal related to JCPDS Card No 33-0480. Also the other peaks at 32° and 39° with the planes of (110) and (220) monoclinic phase of CuO with JCPDS Card No 05-0661. The sharp peaks in the XRD spectrum are in the good crystalline structure of CuO nanoparticle. Another peak appears in the sample S2 at 15.6° which is attributed to the same plane (101), may be the peak has been splitted into two due to the diffraction or within experimental error. The XRD pattern of the prepared nanoparticles indicates an additional peak at 24.8° attributed to the (002) plane of the hexagonal graphite structure, resulting from the incorporation of reduced graphene oxide into the CuZnCdO metallic nanoparticles. Due to the dopant materials (Cadmium and Zinc) the peak has been shift in the XRD is based on the dopant size. If the dopant size is smaller than the base metal, it will occupy the interstitial position on the structure which leads to change in the lattice structure. Thus the d-spacing between the atoms become very less so there is an increase in the X-ray diffraction resulting in higher angles (2θR). Even it may broadened the peak and suppress the intensity when the concentration of the dopants was increasing instead of new peaks. From Debye–Scherrer’s formula, the average crystallite size was found to be 7.12 nm, 7.45 nm, and 7.6 nm for S1, S2, and S3. The ionic radii of Copper, Zinc, and Cadmium were 0.73 Å, 0.74 Å, and 0.95 Å. Here comparing to Copper, Zinc, and Cadmium has the highest ionic radii, so the concentration of dopant increases the crystallite size has also increased.Fig. 2
XRD Pattern of rGO/CuZnCdO (S1, S2, S3) nanoparticles

sec.title: FESEM and EDAX analysis
sec.p:
The FESEM image of rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles has shown in Fig. 3a–c. It is evident that the synthesized rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles have appeared in the sphere-like structure for all the three samples resulting that dopant concentration doesn’t alter the morphology of the material. The figure clearly shows the porous nature of the synthesized materials, which confirms the incorporation of CuZnCdO nanoparticles into the reduced Graphene oxide sheets. The particle size has been found to be 7.6 nm, 9.8 nm, and 12.3 nm for S1, S2, and S3 which clearly shows that the particle size increases while the concentration increases. In Fig. 3d–f the EDAX spectrum shows only Copper, Zinc, Cadmium, Carbon, and Oxygen which confirms the purity of rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles for all the three samples. The elements percentage for the entire three samples was showed in Table 1a–c. Fig. 3
a–c FESEM Micrographs, d–f EDAX spectrum, and for rGO/CuZnCdO (S1, S2, S3) nanoparticlesTable 1

sec.title: BET analysis
sec.p:
Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method is used to measure the specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter for rGO/CuZnCdO (S1, S2, and S3). The specific surface area and pore diameter distribution are playing a pivotal role in bringing forth adequate capacitive performance. As reported in the Table 2 when increasing the dopant concentration crystallite size has also been increased, it may decrease the surface area as well vice versa. S2 is showing different pore volume and diameter due to ageing process or annealing temperature or some instrumental error. In Table 2 resulting that S1 has a high surface area than the other due to the dopant concentrations the crystallite size is smaller. Debye–Scherrer’s Equation is used to calculating the crystallite size from X-ray diffraction. Thus S1 has the largest number of reactive power and high specific surface area which leads to accommodate the largest charge capacitive without any decay in electrochemical performance.Table 2
BET analysis of rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles

sec.title: Optical analysis
sec.p:
In Fig. 4a, the UV Vis absorption spectra of rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles have shown. The absorption peak of the nanoparticles is observed to be 286 nm, 281 nm, and 278 nm for all the three concentrations it is evident that the prepared material has somewhat larger than the reported value. It may be due to the dopant concentration was larger than the other 2 samples, slightly the absorption pattern has changed for S3. Thus, the rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles showed a significant red shift. This can be determined by the enhanced visible light of the synthesized nanoparticles. The optical band gap has been calculated from Tauc’s plot provided in Fig. 4b estimated were 1.54 eV, 1.62 eV and 1.78 eV for S1, S2, and S3 respectively shows the indirect bandgap. Whereas the particle size is increased and the red shift has been decreased.Fig. 4
a Absorbance spectra of rGO/CuZnCdO (S1, S2, S3) nanoparticles. b Tauc’s plot of rGO/CuZnCdO (S1, S2, S3) nanoparticles

sec.title: FTIR and FT-RAMAN analysis
sec.p:
The functional groups of the rGO/CuZnCdO indicated in Fig. 5a ranging between the 4000 and 400 cm−1. The C–O stretching vibrations of epoxy groups of GO band observed at 1112 and 1405 cm−1, C–O stretching vibrations at 1266 cm−1, 3460 cm−1, 3323 cm−1, and 3178 cm−1 O–H vibrations of C–OH tertiary groups, 1624 cm−1 is C=C stretching vibration confirms the rGO sheets. Cd–O stretching mode at 935 cm−1, 622 cm1 is Cu–O stretching, and 838 cm−1 and 472 cm1 are Zn–O Stretching vibrations. The absorption spectra confirm the presence of Cd, Cu, Zn metals and reduced graphene sheets for all three concentrations and also the stretching of OH bonds. Figure 5b exhibits the Raman spectra of the synthesized rGO/CuZnCdO in the range of 1000–2000 cm−1. A Raman spectrum is the essential characterization analysis for graphene-based materials. The spectrum reveals the single, bi & multilayer graphene or graphene oxide materials. It is evident that the G band occurs at 1598 cm−1 and D band occurs at 1341 cm−1 affirms the prepared materials were single-layer reduced graphene oxide for all the three samples.Fig. 5
a FTIR Spectrum of rGO/CuZnCdO (S1, S2, S3) nanoparticles. b FT-Raman Spectra of rGO/CuZnCdO (S1, S2, S3) nanoparticles

sec.title: Cyclic Voltammetry
sec.p: The estimation of electrochemical performance for synthesized rGO/CuZnCdO (S1, S2, and S3) nanoparticles using Cyclic Voltammetry with three electrode systems, a platinum rod as a counter electrode, Ag/Agcl as a reference electrode and rGO/CuZnCdO as a working electrode in an electrochemical workstation (CHI 660, China). 6 M of KOH solution has been utilized as the electrolyte for performing CV analysis at room temperature. 5 mg of synthesized material was dissipated in methanol solution and sonicated for 1 h to form a homologous solution.

Figure 6a–c shows the CV curves of the rGO/CuZnCdO electrode with a different scan rate in the potential range of − 2 to 2 V indicating that the electrochemical behavior of the material is pseudocapacitive behavior. It is evident from the electric double-layer capacitance ascribed by CV curves. The oxidation and reduction process rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles have been defined by the anodic peaks and cathodic peaks in the CV curves. While increasing the scan rates from 10 to 100 mV/s, the anodic and cathodic peaks were shifted to higher and lower potentials which may be due to the polarization. Even though the electrode material has a phenomenal reversible redox reaction with appropriating a symmetric redox peak when the scan rate accretes to 100 mV/s. The CV curves have been evidently different from the typical rectangular shape of EDLC, thus revealing the pseudocapacitive-capacitance characteristics of the rGO/CuZnCdO. While increasing the scan rate, the peak current and the integral areas of the rGO/CuZnCdO has also increased, this reveals the fast charge-transfer and ion-insertion or ion-desertion. Meanwhile, CV curves were maintained at low scan rates, and three pairs of redox peaks could be observed, reveals the good reversibility of the charge carrier. However, at the high scan rates the distortion could be found in the CV curve, observing the two anodic peaks and two broad cathodic peaks were indicates the redox mechanism which was dominant by the mass transfer [42]. Galvanostatic charge–discharge measurement was carried out for rGO/CuZnCdO with the different current density is demonstrated in Fig. 6d–f. The triangular shape of the charge–discharge curve indicates that the electrochemical behavior of the rGO/CuZnCdO is pseudocapacitive, which explicit from the electric double layer capacitor by the CV curve. It can be seen that when the current density was increased, evidently the discharge time of the material decreased. This could be due to the stagnant kinetics of the redox reaction to fast potential change [43]. There are many factors can affect the specific capacitance of the electrode such as specific surface area, pore size, and conductivity [44]. The regular triangular curve indicates an electric double layer capacitor and a plateau indicates a pseudocapacitor, with long charging and discharging time. This may be accredited to the mixed pseudocapacitive or battery type behavior of the electrode, implementing diffusion of electrolyte and interpolation of ionic species.Fig. 6
a–c CV curve with different scan rates, d–f Galvanostatic charge–discharge, g plots of the scan rate versus specific capacitance, h plots of cycle number versus specific capacitance, i Nyquist plot, j Bode plot of rGO/CuZnCdO (S1, S2, S3) nanoparticles

Figure 6g exhibits the specific capacitance of the rGO/CuZnCdO at various scan rates of 10 to 100 mV/s. The specific capacitance of 883 F/g, 776 F/g, and 694 F/g at a scan rate of 10 mV/s for S1, S2, and S3 which clearly shows that S1 (whose concentration X = 0.1) has high specific capacitance than S2 and S3. Whereas increasing the scan rate from 10 to 100 mV/s, the specific capacitance has been gradual decreases attributable to the ion diffusion from the electrolyte. At high current density, a few electrolyte ions do not play a part in the Faradaic redox reaction ascribed to the low electron transfer and slow ions diffusion. In this case, at high current densities, the charge storage was applied only by the outer active surface, resulting in that the electroactive materials have been utilized the lower electrochemical performance. In power applications, it is the most essential criteria to rating the capability of supercapacitors usage. The material is prescribed to produce high energy density at a high charge/discharge rate to achieve good electrochemical performance with high stability.

Electrochemical Impedance Spectrum is estimating the information of rGO/CuZnCdO, which was performed from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz at the open circuit potential with an ac perturbation of 5 mV. The cyclic stability of the rGO/CuZnCdO was estimated for 5000 continuous cycles at 10 mV/s were displayed in Fig. 6h. It can be seen that 92.6% of the initial specific capacitance can be retrieved after 3000 cycles and 85% of capacitance is deathly sustained even after 5000 cycles, resulting in that the specific capacitance of rGO/CuZnCdO electrode material cultivates the large cyclic stability without any decay, so it is highly suitable for supercapacitors. Nyquist plot of the rGO/CuZnCdO is shown in Fig. 6i. The insertion of the Nyquist plot has been enhanced and shown data from 0 to 1. The equivalent series resistance extrapolated from X-axis is about 0.62 Ω for S1, 0.61 Ω for S2, and S3 respectively. It indicates that the ESR decreases when the concentration is increased, this may be attributed to the electron transfer from the dopants. Finally, there is no semicircle is observed in the Nyquist plot for the high frequency range in the x-axis, which indicates low charge-transfer resistance. In further, the impedance curve has been demonstrating the high electrochemical cyclic stability for rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles. The Bode plot was shown in Fig. 6j which demonstrates the characteristic of relaxation time, and frequency versus impedance phase angle.

In further, the CV curve for all the three samples of scan rates at 10 mV/s was shown in Fig. 7a resulting that the sample S1 has the broad rectangular curve thus exhibits the electric double layer capacitance. Meanwhile, Fig. 7b exhibits the isosceles triangular shapes of Galvanostatic Charge–Discharge curves at current density of 15 A/g, it is evident the that S1 has the highest charge carrier concentration and capacitive behavior.Fig. 7
a CV Curve at a scan rate of 10 mV/s, b GCD curve at a current density of 15 A/g and c Ragone plot for rGO/CuZnCdO (S1, S2, S3) nanoparticles

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Reduced graphene oxide derived from A. heterophyllus dead leaves which are eco-friendly and cost-effective. The CuZnCdO metallic nanoparticles have been synthesized by the co-precipitation technique using a plant extract of A. heterophyllus (fresh leaves) as a reducing agent. Finally, the optimized rGO/CuZnCdO (S1) whose concentration (X = 0.1) occurs a high pore volume of 0.69 cm3 g−1, and a high surface area of 615.7 m2 g−1. The highest specific capacitance was found to be 883 F/g at the current density of 10 mV/s with an effective electrical conductivity and excellence cyclic stability about 85% of capacitance is deathly sustained even after 5000 cycles. The equivalent series resistance has been extrapolated from X-axis is about 0.62 Ω for S1, 0.61 Ω for S2, and S3 respectively. It indicates that the ESR decreases when the concentration is increased, this may be attributed to the electron transfer from the dopants. Further, the energy density of rGO/CuZnCdO nanoparticles is observed to be 9.14 W h kg−1 at a power density of 205 W kg−1, and it remains up to 3.9 W h kg−1 at a power density of 9482.1 W kg−1. Moreover, rGO-CuZnCdO vows the high electrochemical performance notably from the reuse of dead leaves and further, it may lead to a fabrication process for energy storage devices.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors wish to thank National Physical Laboratory, Delhi for the characterization facilities of this research work.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest. The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
